body:
I have not read through all the sources of ASK, but my impression is that many elements which combine into a keyboard layout (such as `The Top Row`) are described by ‚Äújust an XML file‚Äù which is read and processed *at run-time*.  So why not make these editable at run-time?!

**If so:**

Suppose that 
* in the dialogue for choosing `The Top Row` there appear 10 other choices: ‚ÄúCustom 1‚Äù, ‚Ä¶, ‚ÄúCustom 10‚Äù.  
* Initially, these extra choices are ‚Äúempty‚Äù.
* When long-pressing on a ‚Äúusual, not-`Custom`‚Äù variant of the choice of top row (or maybe in the `‚ãÆ`-menu when it is selected) there is a choice ‚Äúgo to the XML of this variant‚Äù.  (Just a link to the GitHub page.)
* Additionally, on these ‚Äúnew‚Äù `Custom N` choices, there is a similar choice to `Edit the XML`‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhich just shows a standard multiline text-entry editor.   (It is OK if a restart is required after editing‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut I do not see why this may be so‚Ä¶)

These 3 enhancement seem to be easy to implement‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut I think this may be a great first step to make the layout editable.  For example, later one may 
* Write (simple!) scripts processing other (easier-to-write) formats into XML-understood-by-ASK; 
* Yet later, one may enable plug-ins which allow these other formats processed at the run-time (by ``Import another format`‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâin addition to `Edit the XML`).
title: Proposal: A simple way to make ASK-keyboards customizable

body:
With the existing tweak to make the extra pop-up rows ‚Äústicky‚Äù, there is a chance to make them ‚Äúhonest‚Äù (of course, in the sticky-state only):
* allow sliding-off-keysboard-area to cancel long-pressing-on-a-key;
* allow long-press and alternative-characters on these rows.

(Of course, it would not hurt to also make these rows customizable (the same way as the top-row is customizable).)
title: The extra pop-up rows: not honest-rows

body:
(Unfortunately, I cannot find how to change the Top and bottom rows in the settings anymore, so cannot check the details of the current UI.)

However, I have seen the discussion that the selected keyboard layouts may be changed by slide-reordering‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâso suppose that the same holds for the UI for choosing the top and bottom rows.  Then if one allows multiple checkmarks on the variants of these rows, it seems that that one may get some benefits (e.g., have the terminal top row combined with numbers-row).
title: Choosing the Top and bottom rows: allow multiple choices?

body:
Today I spent a lot of time trying to find the tweak which enables hints.  Could not‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâeven with the help from AI (very thorough‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut wrong!).  (Well, after investigating the issues below, I finally stumbled on this‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâwhile still having no idea how to find it again‚Ä¶  Same for configuring the top and the bottom rows!)

**Thinking about this** more: there is no documentation at all of **the architecture of customizing an ASK keyboard**!  Such a documentation (better present‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâor referred to‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâfrom‚Äâthe home page of the settings-app) should mention (and give clickable links to existing pages in this app) at least: The behavior is controlled by 
* the **repertoire of keys** (which is in turn controlled separately by
    * Top row;
    * ‚ÄúAlpha‚Äú-keys (and the default language);
    * Bottom row
    
    choices)‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand what else???.
* The theme (which controls colors, the display of hints, and **I-have-no-idea-what-else**).
* The tweaks to the shown above entries, as well as
* The generic tweaks (listing the general categories).

---

But as a stopgap measure, there may be a separate entry in the bottom-menu of the settings-app which shows the (clickable!) tree-of-current-hint-pages, and explains (at one location!) the purposes of tweaks on each of these existing tweak pages.
title: Problem with tweaks: how to find them?  (Related to: Problems with hints)

This (preview of) the `Plain Light Theme` (with `English` layout) shows hints with good contrast (thanks!).  However, the shown previews are mostly wrong!

The previews:
* on `Q`  and `W` are correct‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut
* on `E` nothing is shown (out of many), 
* on `R` the character `œÅ` is missing, 
* on `T` the right side of `[t']` is cut off‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand `≈£` and `œÑ` are not shown, 

**Expected behavior**: 
* if the width allows, all the hints should be shown.  
* If not, then the right half of the last shown character should be ‚Äúcut off‚Äù to provide feedback on presence of other variants.
title: Problems with hints: not shown or only partially shown in the UR-position

body:
As I already mentioned in #4651 , some themes disable hints, **silently**.  (Well, **if one knows what to expect**, there may be some feedback since ‚Äúthe preview on top of the settings-page does not show hints‚Äù.  But how would one know that this preview **should react on the enabled settings**?!  (Actually, I realized that I do not know whether it does!)

One could get a bit more feedback comparing to what the preview shows *for other themes*‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâbut this also does not work!  The second problem is that most of the light-themes either do not show the hints at all (at least not the way I can see)‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâor show them with such a low contrast that I have been missing this display until I tried to ‚Äúpay special attention‚Äù.  The only exception among standard themes is the *Plain Light Theme*.

**Expected behavior:** if a theme supports hints, they should be shown with sufficient contrast (or with an outline in a contrasting color).  (If this is annoying for people with extra-sharp vision, this may be disabled by a configurable setting.)
title: Problems with hints: no support from most of the themes

body:
When choosing a theme, its description has no feedback on whether hints are going to be shown in this theme.  In particular, I spent hour(s) trying to understand why no matter how I re-configure, hints would not show.  (Alas, AIs are not of help here‚Ä¶)

Expected behavior: 
* the theme description should list which **configurable** ‚Äúfeatures‚Äù **are going to be disabled**.
* The description for the enable-hints (etc.?) UI-element  switch should mention that this may be overridden by the theme.

Thanks!
title: Problems with hints: no feedback when choosing theme

body:
### Feature idea **Related optimization problem and use case** This Feature Request aims to *optimize writing speed of correct written words*. It's adressing fast typers. *Fast typing* is hereby defined by >= ~200 keys per minute (you can test e.g. [here](https://www.speedtypingonline.com/typing-test)). It can be achived by e.g. using both thumbs (which here may be assumed). **Key observations for the problem** *1. The optimal gazing point while typing is imo in the ~middle of the keyboard.* This way the periphal gaze can catch all the keys on the keyboard best. This increases the typing precision.


You see the gaze is a bit higher than middle, this may be good because the thumbs might be blocking the view on the lower position for the overlay (but that I'm currently not sure about, because the thumbs are normally moving). *2. The high feedback loop with suggested word forecasting (while typing) probably isn't useful for most fast typers.* Fast typers are so fast that the cost of viewing the possible suggestion-completions (and recognizing them) is higher than just typing the word to end fast. *3. Still: A low-cognitive-profile feedback of what is typed, is still useful for improving accuracy of key-typing* Seeing which letters are currently hit is probably still interesting for improving key-typing accuracy. It has a low-cognitive-profile because that is currently, what was mentally adressed anyway and should typically be exspected result (except when a wrong key was hit). Also it can be showed where the gaze already is in place. *4. Still: To see a word was written wrongly (and also correct it) is still useful, especially if the word was completley written.* This can be done by showing the current/last word on the gazing place. Also, if auto-correction is on (probably recommendable), the words should came out as wanted (because it was manually typed) in most cases if it wasn't corrected. And if it was corrected by the auto-correction it can be shown in place and also make the phone vibrate. This should appear when the **spacebar was hit, showing the current wordwriting is finished** . **Solution** On the gazing position (~middle keyboard) an overlay can be shown, which shows the current word. - The last letter of the word always stands in the same place (new key types push the "old" letters to the left, so the word grows to the left). - When the space-key is pressed and it wasn't autocorrected, it still shows the same word (maybe only for at most 3 seconds unitl the overlay hides). If a key for a new key is pressed and a new word begins, the overlay shows the first word letter (begins anew). - When the space-key is pressed and it was autocorrected, the overlay shows the autocorrected word on them same position (and maybe the phone vibrates in low volume). The written word is shown above crossed out. - (If the auto-correction was right relevant) Same behavior as above with 3 seconds (or so) until the overlay hides, or alternativly a new word was begon. - If the auto-correction was wrong. Click/swype for showing all possible other corrections including the original writing. Or delete the last single letters or delete the whole word. I think it's best to see what I mean in an animated GIF, so I made one (which took longer to make than i exspected, but hopefully it has some value), click to make it bigger:

(The overlay is transparent)

The last written letter could be emphasized in some way, but such things are details. Small adjustment: It would be good if there would be a visual emphasis on the current letter, (which is the watch anchor / gaze anchor / focal point) and typing is using peripheral vision. E.g. by a highlighting with an additional background rectangle. E.g. like this:

(the rectangle isn't perfect matching the letter and it's color could be better, but you see, what i mean)
title: [Feature request] Overlay for fast typers (overlay shows current/last written word)

Ever since the v1.12 F-droid release (coming from v1.11 on F-droid) I noticed that the suggestions bar (i.e. CandidateView.java) is rendered with dark theme colors, despite me using the Lean Light theme.

I just found out it's because of this piece of code:
https://github.com/AnySoftKeyboard/AnySoftKeyboard/blob/19f1f2ae8a26917bc1384baf89288f4e225f03da/ime/app/src/main/java/com/anysoftkeyboard/keyboards/views/CandidateView.java#L116-L119

The call to `OverlayDataNormalizer.normalize()` is done with `overlay.getPrimaryDarkColor()` and `overlay.getSecondaryTextColor()` both being zero (is the overlay object missing something?), resulting in `OverlayDataNormalizer.normalize()` defaulting to `return new OverlayDataNormalized(original, Color.WHITE, Color.LTGRAY);`.

So the fix would be to make sure the overlay object contains actual theme color settings before entering `OverayDataNormalizer.normalize()`, because if I replace the variable `normalized` with `overlay` on https://github.com/AnySoftKeyboard/AnySoftKeyboard/blob/19f1f2ae8a26917bc1384baf89288f4e225f03da/ime/app/src/main/java/com/anysoftkeyboard/keyboards/views/CandidateView.java#L119 then I see the correct colors for the Lean Light theme in the suggestion bar.
title: [Bug] Suggestion bar defaults to dark theme even when using light theme

When configuring AnySoftKeyboard, and selecting a submenu, to return to the calling menu, one has to quit the configuration, go back into configuration via Android preferences/System/Language&Input/AnySoftKeyboard configuration, to restart configuration.

This makes it extremely difficult to explore the configuration menus to find the appropriate configuration for one's needs.

For example, I wanted to change the top menu, so instead of taking 30 seconds to find the right place, it took me maybe 30 minutes before giving up and another 20 minutes to find the wiki and find the answer.  Afterwards it was quick to find that solution.  For other changes, I had to go through the same process.
That is anything but user friendly.

Typically, like for Android itself, configuration submenus have a left arrow top left, to allow returning to the calling menu.
Such a feature would be critically important for AnySoftKeyboard, which has a somewhat complex menu system.  It would be "light years" easier to configure.

Thank you for an otherwise great application.
title: Submenus need to be able to back out to calling menu.
